bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, July 9, 1928

div1.p: Carter describes the offers of assistance she has received from Col. Ashburn and Dr. Thayer and praises Brown's considerable efforts.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, July 9, 1928
div1.opener:
Carbon for file.
Book
Russell
(Report)
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
July 9, 1928.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
As I told you in my letter of July 2nd., work on the purely medical
(and last) section of the bibliography of the History of Yellow Fever was
begun on Sunday, July 1st. Since that time Miss Brown and I have made
considerable progress therein at the Library of Congress.

I have also had the very real pleasure of seeing Colonel Ashburn and
talking over with him the best plans for the work remaining to be done on
the medical bibliography. Colonel Ashburn agrees with me that I had best
stay at the Library of Congress as long as possible--i. e. as long as I
can get medical references from its files to clear up before I move to the
Library of the Surgeon General of the Army. This, because the facilities
for such work at the Library of Congress are greater (as to working space
etc.) than he can offer me at the Library of the Surgeon General, even withwhen
the special priveleges of staying after hours: taking books home etc. are
taken into account, all of which he has most kindly and helpfully said he
would giveafford me. Colonel Ashburn has also offered to give special desk
space to myself and Miss Brown. Indeed, no one could have been more kind
and thoughtful than he has shown himself.

Washington is a “burning, fiery furnace” these days, despite which
fact Miss Brown and I put in ten hours of intensive work on July 4th.--this
not counting time off for meals. It was pretty strenuous “going,” but will
save us several days time astaking into account how our respective working hours are arranged. I
do hope you're having better weather in New York. Its really quite dread-
ful here, but so long as one can “carry on” efficiently comfort is a minor
consideration.

Dr. Thayer continues to be most helpful in facilitating and expediting
my work. Indeed, I can never adequately express my appreciation of all that
he has done, and is doing, in this respect.
etc.
